channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: American Jihadist Is Believed Killed by Ex-Allies in Somalia
item.description: Omar Hammami, who grew up in Alabama, was known for his rap-infused propaganda videos for the Shabab, a brutal Islamist group.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: Mr. Hammami, also known by the nom de guerre Abu Mansoor Al-Amriki, “the American,” has been declared dead before, only to resurface alive.

item.title: U.S. to Gauge Viability of Arms Plan in Russia Talks
item.description: As Secretary of State John Kerry arrived for talks in Geneva Thursday, American officials said they were planning to determine if Russia and Syria were serious about a plan to secure Syria’s chemical arsenal.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry before testifying Tuesday in the House. Now he faces talks in Geneva with his Russian counterpart on how to secure and destroy Syria’s chemical weapons.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: September 12
item.description: A worker at a carpet manufacturing factory in Jammu city, Jammu and Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: An employee working at the production line of a carpet manufacturing factory in Jammu city, Jammu and Kashmir.

item.title: India Ink: India Restarts Battle Against Leprosy
item.description: India has declared that it has leprosy under control, but the numbers are showing a slow but clear rise in new cases.
item.dc:creator: By ANJALI THOMAS
item.media:description: A leprosy patient speaking about her problems during an awareness campaign in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh, on Apr. 3.

item.title: New Attack Raises Fears of Broader Threat in Philippines
item.description: Government forces are now dealing with two separate outbreaks of violence in the southern Philippines.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: European Lawmakers Expand Power of Central Bank
item.description: The European Parliament approved a law that puts about 150 of the euro zone’s largest banks under the scrutiny of the European Central Bank.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Michel Barnier, the European Union commissioner overseeing financial services, at the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France, on Thursday.

item.title: Prince William to Leave British Military
item.description: After seven years of service, mainly as a search-and-rescue helicopter pilot, the royal family said the prince would focus on charitable work and conservation.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: India Ink: Hospital Confronts Childbirth Deaths in Mumbai Slum
item.description: The efforts of community volunteers and doctors at Chotta Sion hospital toward improving maternal and infant mortality rates in Mumbai’s Dharavi slum are threatened by the rising population.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL EDISON HAYDEN
item.media:description: A view of the Dharavi slum in Mumbai, Maharashtra, on July 31, 2012.

item.title: Letter From Europe: England, the Land of Hope and Worry
item.description: In the past few days, the English have been peppered with what might once have been considered heresies or, at least, affronts to their long-cherished sense of a natural order.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Second Newspaper Group Under Inquiry in British Hacking Scandal
item.description: Trinity Mirror, the owner of tabloids including The Daily Mirror and The Sunday Mirror, said an inquiry had been opened into its criminal liability for the actions of former employees.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Australian Politician Seeks to Take Over Labor Party
item.description: Bill Shorten has pledged to keep the party’s signature achievement: an emissions trading plan that many Australians don’t like.
item.dc:creator: By MATT SIEGEL
item.media:description: Bill Shorten announced on Thursday that he would seek the Labor Party’s leadership.

item.title: Prosecutors Seek Death Penalty in India Rape Case
item.description: Prosecutors argued that the public would be outraged by anything less than death for four men who participated in the rape and murder of a 23-year-old student in December.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Crude Oil in Runaway Train Was Mislabeled
item.description: The runaway train that exploded, killing 47 people and destroying much of Lac-Mégantic, Quebec, was far more volatile than signs on its tank cars indicated, investigators said.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Politician Leaves a Post After Assault Charges
item.description: A deputy speaker of Parliament, Nigel Evans, resigned from the post after he was charged with eight counts of sexual assault, including rape, dating from 2002 until this year.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Poland: Workers Stage Protest as Economy Slows
item.description: Thousands of Polish labor union members marched through Warsaw to protest against government labor policy and overhauls to the pension system, and to demand higher pay.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: To Avoid Trial, State Pays Family of Prisoner X
item.description: Israel has reached a compensation agreement with the family of Ben Zygier, an Australian-Israeli who was jailed in Israel and who died after hanging himself in his cell in 2010.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Bomb Attacks on Shiite Mosque Kill 33
item.description: A coordinated car bomb and suicide bomb attack on a Shiite mosque in Baghdad killed at least 33 people and wounded 55, the police and medical officials said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Saul Landau, Maker of Films With Leftist Edge, Dies at 77
item.description: Mr. Landau’s passion for asking what he called “the most intrusive questions” yielded penetrating cinematic profiles of leaders like Fidel Castro and Salvador Allende.
item.category: Paul Jacobs and the Nuclear Gang (Movie)
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
item.media:credit: Institute for Policy Studies, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Saul Landau with Subcommander Marcos of the Zapatistas in Chiapas, Mexico, in 1995. Mr. Landau was also a prolific writer.

item.title: Afghan Army Struggles in District Under Siege
item.description: The Sangin district in Afghanistan offers a troubling portrait of life where the Taliban decide to make their mark and the Americans no longer fight.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: An Afghan National Army soldier at Transformer, a combat outpost in Sangin district in Helmand Province. The Taliban have weathered the Afghans’ halfhearted efforts to reclaim Sangin.

item.title: Militants Kill Soldiers in Sinai, and Egypt’s Military Broadens Its Crackdown
item.description: The new Egyptian government said it was stepping up its crackdown on Islamist militants there and also appeared to be moving against non-Islamist voices of dissent.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: The Egyptian military is cracking down on militants in Sinai who have lashed out.

item.title: U.S. and Russia Far Apart on Eve of Talks Over Syria
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry headed to talks with his Russian counterpart, Sergey V. Lavrov, on how to secure and ultimately destroy Syria’s chemical weapons.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry before testifying Tuesday in the House. Now he faces talks in Geneva with his Russian counterpart on how to secure and destroy Syria’s chemical weapons.

item.title: A Rare Public View of Obama’s Pivots on Policy in Syria Confrontation
item.description: President Obama’s handling of his confrontation with Syria has been an unusual instance of a commander in chief seemingly thinking out loud and changing his mind on the fly.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: Syrian government troops on Tuesday in the town of Maalula after they beat back Islamist rebels, for whom the town near Damascus is strategically important.

item.title: North Korea Appears to Restart Plutonium Reactor
item.description: New satellite images show steam emerging from a nuclear reactor in North Korea, suggesting that the country may be making good on its promise to resume the production of plutonium for its small nuclear arsenal.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER, WILLIAM J. BROAD and CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: As Obama Pauses Action, Putin Takes Center Stage
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin has, at least for now, made Russia indispensable in containing the conflict in Syria.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: Pictures of Bashar al-Assad and Vladimir V. Putin were displayed in March outside the Russian Embassy in Damascus, Syria.

item.title: Linking Hands, Catalans Press Case for Secession
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of people waved flags and joined hands across Catalonia, in a show of popular force that Catalan leaders hope will revive their push for secession from Spain.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Edu Bayer for the International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Catalans in Barcelona were among hundreds of thousands in a human chain on Wednesday to show support for separating from Spain.
